question:
Which of the following uprisings took place in Bengal just after the Revolt of 1857?

I.A.S. (Pre) 1994
solution:
• The Indigo Rebellion (Nile Rebellion) took place in Bengal in 1859–60, just after the Revolt of 1857.
  • It was led by indigo cultivators (ryots) who refused to grow indigo under exploitative contracts imposed by European planters.
  • Ryots were forced to grow indigo on fertile land, received unfair payments, and were often subjected to physical coercion and legal pressure.
  • The rebellion spread rapidly in Nadia, Jessore, Pabna, and other districts of Bengal.
  • The movement was largely non-violent but highly effective in resisting British indigo interests.
  • In response, the British government appointed the Indigo Commission in 1860, which acknowledged the ryots' grievances and declared they could refuse to grow indigo.

Additional Information:

  • Sanyasi Rebellion occurred in the late 18th century, much earlier than 1857.
  • Santhal Rebellion happened in 1855–56, just before the 1857 revolt.
  • Pabna Rebellion took place in the 1870s, later than the Indigo revolt.

question:
What was the 'Nile Rebellion' about?

B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2018
option_1: The ryots did not want to cultivate indigo, but were being forced to do so.
option_2: The ryots wanted to cultivate indigo, but were being forced to do so.
option_3: The ryots did not want to cultivate indigo, but were being forced to do so at an unfair price.
option_4: A rebel movement with a blue flag.
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The Nile Rebellion (Indigo Rebellion) was a peasant uprising that occurred in Bengal in 1859–60, shortly after the 1857 revolt.
  • It arose because ryots (farmers) did not want to cultivate indigo, but were forced to do so by European planters at unfair and exploitative prices.
  • The planters used coercion, threats, and legal manipulation to extract indigo cultivation on the best lands.
  • Farmers received very low returns, while the crop ruined soil fertility and left them in debt.
  • The widespread resistance led to the formation of the Indigo Commission in 1860, which ruled in favor of the ryots and granted them the freedom to reject indigo cultivation.

Additional Information:

  • The rebellion began in Nadia district and spread to Jessore, Pabna, and other parts of Bengal.
  • Harish Chandra Mukherjee and Dinabandhu Mitra (author of the famous play Nil Darpan) supported the movement through writing and journalism.
  • The movement is considered a precursor to later peasant movements in India.

question:
Who was the author of the book 'Neel Darpan' written on the plight of nile farmers?

42nd B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1997
solution:
• The book 'Neel Darpan' was written by Deenbandhu Mitra in 1860.
  • It is a Bengali play that depicts the sufferings of indigo farmers (ryots) under the exploitation of European indigo planters in Bengal.
  • The play powerfully illustrates the cruelty, coercion, and social injustice faced by the farmers during the Indigo Rebellion (1859–60).
  • 'Neel Darpan' created a major impact on the Bengali society and also gained attention from British officials, some of whom considered it a threat to colonial authority.

Additional Information:

  • The English translation of the play was done by Michael Madhusudan Dutt, and the publication was supported by Rev. James Long, who was later fined and imprisoned by the British for aiding in its publication.
  • The play became a symbol of resistance literature and is considered one of the earliest works of political drama in colonial India.

question:
Who wrote the famous play 'Neel Darpan' which depicted the oppression of indigo farmers?

66th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2020
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The famous play ‘Neel Darpan’ was written by Dinabandhu Mitra in 1860.
  • It powerfully portrayed the brutal oppression and exploitation faced by indigo farmers (ryots) in Bengal under European indigo planters.
  • The play was written in Bengali and set during the period of the Indigo Rebellion (1859–60).
  • It highlighted how planters forced farmers to grow indigo on fertile land under threats, violence, and low compensation.

Additional Information:

  • The English translation was done by Michael Madhusudan Dutt, and its publication was supported by Rev. James Long, who was penalized by the British for printing it.
  • The play stirred public opinion and is considered one of the earliest political dramas in Indian literature.
  • It contributed significantly to social awareness during British rule and inspired future resistance movements.

question:
Who was the author of the play 'Neel Darpan’?

U.P.P.C.S. (Mains) 2015
solution:
• The play ‘Neel Darpan’ was authored by Dinabandhu Mitra in 1860.
  • It vividly depicted the suffering of indigo farmers (ryots) in Bengal at the hands of British indigo planters.
  • The play was written in Bengali and is set during the Indigo Rebellion of 1859–60.
  • It brought to light the exploitation, coercion, and injustice faced by Indian peasants who were forced to grow indigo under harsh conditions.

Additional Information:

  • The English translation was done by Michael Madhusudan Dutt, and its publication was supported by Rev. James Long, who was later penalized by the British.
  • ‘Neel Darpan’ is recognized as one of the earliest social and political plays in Indian literature.
  • The play had a strong public impact, making people aware of the colonial economic exploitation and inspired literary activism in the 19th century.

question:
Which one of the following caused the decline of indigo cultivation in India in the early twentieth century?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2020
option_1: Farmers' protest against the oppressive behaviour of indigo growers
option_2: New discoveries making it unprofitable in the world market
option_3: National leaders' opposition to indigo cultivation
option_4: Government control over growers
solution:
• The decline of indigo cultivation in India in the early 20th century was mainly due to new scientific discoveries.
  • The invention of synthetic dyes (especially aniline dyes developed in Germany) made natural indigo less profitable and gradually obsolete in the global market.
  • As synthetic alternatives were cheaper, more stable, and easier to produce, the demand for Indian indigo declined rapidly.
  • This economic shift had a far greater impact on the decline than political or social movements.

Additional Information:

  • While farmers’ protests like the Indigo Rebellion (1859–60) highlighted the exploitation by planters, they occurred decades before the industry’s collapse.
  • Leaders like Gandhi did support indigo farmers later (e.g., Champaran Satyagraha in 1917), but that was more about labour rights than market viability.
  • Thus, the main reason was the loss of competitiveness of natural indigo due to synthetic dye production.

question:
Consider the following statements with reference to Bankim Chandra Chatterjee :

He was the first graduate of Calcutta University.

2. 'Sitaram' was his last novel.

Select the correct answer using the code given below :

U.P. R.O./A.R.O. (Pre) 2023

Codes:
solution:
Let’s verify both statements regarding Bankim Chandra Chatterjee:

  1. He was the first graduate of Calcutta University – ✔Correct
    • Bankim Chandra Chatterjee was among the first graduates of the University of Calcutta, and he was in fact the first Indian to graduate with honours in Arts in 1858.
  2. ‘Sitaram’ was his last novel – ✔Correct
    • Yes, ‘Sitaram’, published in 1886, is regarded as his last novel.
    • It was a historical novel set in Bengal and carried themes of patriotism and Hindu revivalism.

Hence, both statements are correct.

question:
Who wrote the song 'Vande Mataram’?

Chhattisgarh P.C.S. (Pre) 2005

Uttarakhand U.D.A./L.D.A. (Mains) 2007
solution:
• The song ‘Vande Mataram’ was written by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee in 1875 and later included in his novel ‘Anandamath’, published in 1882.
  • The song praises the motherland and became a symbol of Indian nationalism during the freedom movement.
  • It was originally composed in Sanskritized Bengali and later set to music by Rabindranath Tagore.
  • The first two stanzas of ‘Vande Mataram’ were adopted as the national song of India.

Additional Information:

  • ‘Vande Mataram’ was first sung at the Indian National Congress session in 1896.
  • It inspired countless freedom fighters, and the slogan “Vande Mataram” became a rallying cry against British rule.
  • Bankim Chandra Chatterjee was also one of the pioneers of modern Bengali literature.

question:
Which rebellion is mentioned in Bankim Chandra Chatterjee's 'Anand Math’?

67th B.P.S.C. (Pre), 2021
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The novel ‘Anand Math’ by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee, published in 1882, is set against the backdrop of the Sanyasi Rebellion.
  • The Sanyasi Rebellion took place in late 18th century Bengal, particularly in Murshidabad and Rangpur regions.
  • The novel fictionalizes the armed struggle of sanyasis (ascetics) against the oppressive policies of the British East India Company and local zamindars.
  • It portrays the patriotic spirit and sacrifice of monks fighting for India's liberation and inspired nationalist sentiments.

Additional Information:

  • ‘Anand Math’ is also famous for introducing the patriotic song ‘Vande Mataram’.
  • The novel played a crucial role in fueling early Indian nationalism.
  • The Sanyasi Rebellion occurred around 1770–1800, coinciding with the famine and economic distress in Bengal.

question:
The story of the novel Anandamath is based on-

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1998
option_1: On the Chuar rebellion
option_2: On the Sanyasi rebellion
option_3: On the Paligar rebellion
option_4: On the rebellion of the Talukdars
solution:
• The novel ‘Anandamath’, written by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee and published in 1882, is based on the Sanyasi Rebellion.
  • The Sanyasi Rebellion was a series of armed uprisings by Hindu ascetics (sanyasis) in late 18th century Bengal, especially during the period of British East India Company’s growing dominance.
  • The novel presents a fictionalized and patriotic account of these monks who fought against British oppression and exploitation.
  • It is set during the famine-stricken Bengal of the 1770s and portrays the struggle for freedom and national identity.

Additional Information:

  • ‘Anandamath’ contains the famous patriotic song ‘Vande Mataram’, which later became a national slogan.
  • The novel played a crucial role in inspiring Indian nationalism, especially among the youth and freedom fighters.
  • The Sanyasi Rebellion is considered one of the early resistances against British rule.

question:
Which one of the following revolts was made famous by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee by mentioning it in his novel Anandamath?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2006
option_2: Rangpur and Dinapur rebellion
option_3: Vishnupur and Birbhumi rebellion
solution:
• The revolt made famous by Bankim Chandra Chatterjee in his novel ‘Anandamath’ is the Sanyasi Rebellion.
  • The Sanyasi Rebellion occurred in the late 18th century in Bengal, particularly in the regions of Murshidabad, Dinajpur, and Rangpur.
  • It was led by Hindu ascetics (sanyasis) who rose up against the British East India Company due to economic distress, heavy taxation, and repression during the famine of 1770.
  • In Anandamath, Bankim Chandra reimagines the rebellion as a patriotic and spiritual struggle for India’s freedom.

Additional Information:

  • The novel includes the iconic song ‘Vande Mataram’, which became a symbol of the Indian freedom struggle.
  • Though the actual Sanyasi Rebellion was not nationalist in intent, Bankim’s portrayal transformed it into an inspirational nationalist narrative.
  • The British viewed the Sanyasis as rebels, while the novel elevated them as martyrs for the motherland.

question:
Who among the following gave fame to the 'Sanyasi Rebellion' through his works?

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2017
solution:
• The ‘Sanyasi Rebellion’ (late 18th century) was given nationwide fame and recognition by Bankimchandra Chatterjee through his famous novel Anandamath, published in 1882.
  • Though the rebellion was originally a localized resistance by Hindu ascetics (sanyasis) against British colonial oppression in Bengal, Bankimchandra reimagined it as a patriotic struggle.
  • His portrayal of sanyasis as warriors of freedom infused the rebellion with a nationalist spirit, influencing the Indian independence movement.

Additional Information:

  • Anandamath includes the powerful patriotic song ‘Vande Mataram’, which became a rallying cry during the freedom struggle.
  • The novel turned the Sanyasi Rebellion into a symbol of resistance and made it part of popular nationalist literature.
  • Bankimchandra Chatterjee is thus credited with reviving historical consciousness and patriotic emotion through his literary work.

question:
The plot of Bankim Chandra Chatterjee's famous novel 'Anandamath' is based on-

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 2015
option_1: On the Chuar rebellion
option_2: On the rebellion of Rangpur and Dinajpur
option_3: On the rebellion in Vishnupur and Birbhumi
option_4: On the Sanyasi rebellion
solution:
• The plot of Bankim Chandra Chatterjee's famous novel ‘Anandamath’, published in 1882, is based on the Sanyasi Rebellion.
  • The Sanyasi Rebellion occurred in late 18th century Bengal, especially in areas like Murshidabad, Rangpur, and Dinajpur.
  • It involved Hindu ascetics (sanyasis) and local peasants who revolted against British colonial rule and economic exploitation, particularly during the famine of 1770.
  • Anandamath fictionalizes these events into a patriotic and spiritual struggle, portraying sanyasis as warriors fighting for freedom and justice.

Additional Information:

  • The novel features the iconic song ‘Vande Mataram’, which became the national song of India.
  • It played a major role in inspiring nationalist sentiment during the Indian freedom struggle.
  • Though the actual rebellion was not nationalist in intent, Bankim’s depiction turned it into a symbol of resistance and patriotism.

question:
Which of the following pairs is not correctly matched?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre.) 2017

(Rebellion)- (Year)
option_1: Pabna Rebellion - 1873
option_2: Deccan Peasant Rebellion - 1875
option_3: Sanyasi Rebellion - 1894
option_4: Kol Rebellion - 1831
solution:
Let’s verify each pair:

(a) Pabna Rebellion – 1873✔Correct

  • The Pabna Rebellion occurred in 1873–76 in Eastern Bengal (now Bangladesh).
  • It was a non-violent peasant uprising against zamindars who were demanding excessive rent.

(b) Deccan Peasant Rebellion – 1875✔Correct

  • Took place in the Deccan region of Maharashtra in 1875.
  • Farmers revolted against moneylenders due to indebtedness and land mortgage exploitation.

(c) Sanyasi Rebellion – 1894❌Incorrect

  • The Sanyasi Rebellion occurred in the late 18th century, primarily during 1770–1800.
  • It was led by Hindu ascetics in Bengal against British economic policies and land revenue pressure, especially after the famine of 1770.

(d) Kol Rebellion – 1831✔Correct

  • The Kol Rebellion happened in 1831–32 in the Chotanagpur region (present-day Jharkhand).
  • Tribal communities like the Kols, Mundas, and Oraons rose against British rule and exploitation by outsiders (dikus).

Hence, the incorrectly matched pair is (c).

question:
What was the objective of Munger's Barhiyatal protest?

39th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1994
option_1: Demand for return of Bakasht land
option_2: Stop exploitation of Muslim farmers
option_3: End of Zamindari system
solution:
• The Barhiyatal protest in Munger (Bihar) was a peasant movement with the main objective of demanding the return of Bakasht land.
  • Bakasht land referred to land that tenants had cultivated for a long time, but during zamindari rule, they were evicted or the land was taken over by landlords.
  • The protest aimed to restore the traditional cultivation rights of tenants and resist the forcible occupation of their land by zamindars.
  • This movement was part of broader agrarian unrest in Bihar against feudal exploitation during the colonial period.

Additional Information:

  • The term Bakasht means self-cultivated land, and it was central to many peasant rights movements in Bihar in the early 20th century.
  • The protest reflected the growing awareness among peasants about land rights and agrarian justice.
  • It contributed to the anti-zamindari sentiment, which later became a core part of land reform movements in Bihar.

question:
The main center of the "Wahhabi movement" during the nineteenth century was-

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1994
solution:
• The Wahhabi Movement was an Islamic revivalist movement that emerged in India in the early 19th century.
  • It was inspired by the teachings of Syed Ahmed Barelvi, who was influenced by Abdul Wahhab of Arabia.
  • The movement aimed to restore Islamic purity, oppose British rule, and reject un-Islamic practices.
  • The main center of this movement in India was Patna, particularly the Patna Caliphate, which acted as a base for spreading Wahhabi ideology.
  • Patna served as the organizational and ideological hub for coordination across Bengal, Bihar, and the North-West regions.

Additional Information:

  • Syed Ahmed Barelvi launched a jihad against the Sikh rule in Punjab and was martyred in the Battle of Balakot (1831).
  • The movement later came under surveillance during the British crackdown, especially after the 1857 revolt.
  • The Wahhabi trials were held in the 1860s where leaders were prosecuted by the British for anti-government conspiracies.

question:
Who Organised the Kuka movement?

45th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2001
solution:
• The Kuka Movement was a socio-religious reform movement that emerged in Punjab during the 19th century.
  • It was organized by Guru Ram Singh in 1857, shortly after the Revolt of 1857.
  • The movement aimed to reform Sikhism, promote social equality, oppose idolatry, and resist British colonial rule.
  • Guru Ram Singh advocated Swadeshi (use of Indian goods) and non-cooperation with the British — ideas that predated Gandhi’s movements.

Additional Information:

  • The Kuka followers were also known as Namdharis.
  • The movement emphasized simple living, vegetarianism, and abolition of caste discrimination.
  • The British cracked down harshly on the movement, especially after the Malerkotla incident (1872) where many Kukas were executed.

question:
The foundation of the Kuka movement was laid in-

R.O./A.R. O. (Pre) 2017
solution:
• The Kuka Movement was founded in Punjab, making it a significant reformist movement in Sikh history.
  • It was started in the mid-19th century by Guru Ram Singh with the goal of purifying Sikhism and resisting British colonial rule.
  • The movement emerged as a response to moral degeneration, British policies, and the growing influence of Christian missionaries in Punjab.

Additional Information:

  • The Kukas, also called Namdharis, were prominent in regions like Ludhiana and Malerkotla.
  • The movement focused on reviving Khalsa traditions, banning cow slaughter, and promoting self-rule and Swadeshi ideals.
  • It laid the foundation for early nationalist resistance in North India.

question:
The Pagalpanthi rebellion was actually a rebellion-

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1999
solution:
• The Pagalpanthi Rebellion was primarily a tribal uprising in the northeastern region of India.
  • It was led by Karam Shah and later by his son Tipu, and it took place in the early 19th century in the Mymensingh region (now in Bangladesh).
  • The movement aimed to protest against oppressive revenue collection by landlords and British officials.
  • The followers were known as Pagalpanthis, and many of them were from the Gar (Garo) tribal community.

Correct answer: (b) Gars

Additional Information:

  • The rebellion promoted social equality, protection of the poor peasants, and resistance against exploitative systems.
  • Although it was eventually suppressed by the British, the rebellion reflected early tribal resistance to colonial rule and feudal oppression.

question:
Who founded the 'Pagal Panth’?

56th to 59th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2015
solution:
• The Pagal Panth was a religious and socio-political sect that evolved into a tribal rebellion during British rule.
  • It was founded by Karam Shah in the early 19th century in the Mymensingh district (present-day Bangladesh).
  • The sect combined Islamic mysticism (Sufism) with social reform, attracting marginalized communities, especially the Garos and other local tribes.
  • Karam Shah’s son Tipu later led the Pagalpanthi movement in a more militant direction against British exploitation and zamindari oppression.

Additional Information:

  • The movement opposed high land revenue, corruption, and feudal exploitation.
  • It gained a large following among peasants and tribal people, especially those suffering under British policies.

question:
Who among the following was the leader of Faraji rebellion?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1999
solution:
• The Faraizi Movement was a 19th-century Islamic reform movement in Bengal.
  • It was founded by Haji Shariatullah, but the movement gained momentum under the leadership of his son Dadu Miyan.
  • Dadu Miyan transformed the movement into a mass-based agrarian rebellion against British colonial rule and zamindari oppression.
  • He mobilized peasants, especially Muslim tenants, to resist illegal taxes, forced labor, and exploitative landlords.

Correct answer: (b) Dadu Miyan

Additional Information:

  • The term "Faraizi" comes from Fard, meaning obligatory duties in Islam.
  • The movement began as a religious purification campaign but turned into a socio-political resistance.
  • It was especially strong in Eastern Bengal, including regions like Dhaka, Faridpur, and Barisal.

question:
Who was Faraji?

56th to 59th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2015
option_1: Followers of Haji Shariatullah
option_3: Followers of Arya Samaj
option_4: Followers of Muslim League
solution:
• The term "Faraizi" refers to followers of the Faraizi Movement, which was started in the early 19th century in Bengal.
  • The movement was founded by Haji Shariatullah around 1818.
  • The word "Faraizi" is derived from "Fard", meaning obligatory religious duties in Islam.
  • The Faraizis focused on purifying Islam by strictly following obligatory duties and eliminating un-Islamic practices.
  • Therefore, Faraizis were the followers of Haji Shariatullah.

Correct answer: (a) Followers of Haji Shariatullah

Additional Information:

  • After Haji Shariatullah’s death, the movement was carried forward by his son Dadu Miyan, who added a political and peasant-centric dimension to it.
  • The movement was prominent in Eastern Bengal, especially in Dhaka, Faridpur, and Barisal.

question:
Velu Thampi led the movement against the British-

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2002
solution:
• Velu Thampi was the Dewan (Prime Minister) of the princely state of Travancore in the early 19th century.
  • He is best known for leading a revolt against the British East India Company in 1809.
  • The rebellion was triggered by oppressive British interference in Travancore's administration and heavy financial demands under the Subsidiary Alliance system.
  • Velu Thampi issued the famous Kundara Proclamation, calling upon the people of Travancore to rise against the British.

Correct answer: (a) In Kerala

Additional Information:

  • The rebellion was eventually suppressed by the British, and Velu Thampi died by suicide to avoid capture.
  • Despite its failure, the uprising is remembered as an early expression of Indian resistance against colonial rule.

question:
Read the following statements and choose the correct option-

(i) Ganjam rebellion took place from 1800 to 1805 AD

(ii) Ganjam rebellion was led by Dhananjay

(iii) Gumsur rebellion was led by Shrikar Bhanja

(iv) Dhananjay was the father of Shrikar Bhanja.

Which of the above statements is/are correct?

Chhattisgarh P.C.S. (Pre), 2021
solution:
• Statement (i): Correct

    The Ganjam Rebellion took place between 1800 and 1805 AD in the Ganjam region (present-day Odisha and parts of Andhra Pradesh). It was a tribal uprising against British policies and exploitation.

  • Statement (ii): Correct

    The rebellion was led by Dhananjay, a notable tribal leader who resisted British control in the Ganjam region.

  • Statement (iii): Correct

    The Gumsur Rebellion, a related tribal uprising, was led by Shrikar Bhanja, who belonged to the ruling family of Gumsur.

  • Statement (iv): Incorrect

    Dhananjay was not the father of Shrikar Bhanja. There is no historical evidence supporting this familial relationship. They were leaders of separate but geographically related rebellions.

question:
Who established the Ramoshi Krishak Jatha in Maharashtra?

39th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1994
solution:
• The Ramoshi Krishak Jatha was a revolutionary peasant force formed by Vasudev Balwant Phadke in the 19th century.
  • Phadke believed that British rule was exploiting Indian peasants and weakening the rural economy.
  • He mobilized the Ramoshi tribal community (known for martial traits) in Maharashtra to revolt against British rule.
  • His goal was to loot British treasuries and distribute wealth among the poor farmers.
  • This movement is considered one of the earliest armed uprisings in India against colonial rule.

Additional Information:

  • Vasudev Balwant Phadke is regarded as the first Indian revolutionary who envisioned Swaraj (self-rule) through armed struggle.
  • He established secret networks and raised funds for rebellion through raids.
  • Phadke was eventually arrested and died in Aden (Yemen) in prison in 1883.
  • His efforts later inspired revolutionaries like Bhagat Singh and Subhas Chandra Bose.

question:
In which geographical area did the Ramoshi Rebellion actually take place?

56th to 59th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2015
solution:
• The Ramoshi Rebellion was led by Vasudev Balwant Phadke and other leaders from the Ramoshi tribal community.
  • The Ramoshis were mainly located in the Western Ghats, especially in present-day Maharashtra.
  • Their rebellion was against British colonial policies and economic exploitation after the 1857 revolt.
  • The hilly and forested terrain of the Western Ghats provided strategic cover for guerrilla-style resistance.
  • This rebellion is considered one of the earliest tribal resistances in western India post-1857.

Additional Information:

  • Vasudev Balwant Phadke is often called the father of Indian armed rebellion.
  • The rebellion was suppressed by the British by 1879, but it left a strong imprint on future nationalist movements.
  • The Ramoshi community was historically involved in policing under the Marathas, and their decline post-British rule added to discontent.

question:
Which of the following places was the centre of the Gadkari rebellion?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1999
solution:
• The Gadkari Rebellion was centered in the Kolhapur region of present-day Maharashtra.
  • The Gadkaris were a group of hereditary fort defenders employed under the Maratha administration.
  • After the British took over Kolhapur, the Gadkaris were dismissed and lost their traditional privileges.
  • Their rebellion in the early 19th century was triggered by loss of status and employment under British rule.
  • They used fortresses and guerrilla tactics to resist British suppression.

Additional Information:

  • The British viewed the Gadkaris as a threat to colonial stability and replaced them with a salaried police force.
  • The rebellion was eventually crushed by the British, but it reflected the growing resentment among traditional warrior groups.

question:
Name of the tribe that revolted against the British because of the prohibition of human sacrifice practice –

40th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1995
solution:
• The Khond tribe of Odisha revolted against the British primarily due to the ban on their ritual of human sacrifice (known as Meriah sacrifice).
  • This practice was deeply rooted in their religious and cultural traditions, especially for fertility and agriculture.
  • The British prohibited the Meriah system during their efforts to civilize tribal customs, which led to widespread discontent.
  • The Khonds saw this interference as a direct attack on their traditional faith, sparking a rebellion.
  • The revolt occurred mainly in the Kandhamal and Kalahandi regions of Odisha during the mid-19th century.

Additional Information:

  • The British officer Major Macpherson played a key role in suppressing the Meriah practice.
  • The Khond uprising is one of the earliest tribal uprisings in eastern India against colonial reforms targeting indigenous traditions.

question:
Who led the Kol Rebellion (1831-32 AD)?

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2003
solution:
• The Kol Rebellion of 1831–32 was led by Buddha Bhagat, a tribal leader from the Kol community.
  • The revolt broke out in the Chotanagpur region (present-day Jharkhand) due to British land revenue policies and exploitation by moneylenders and landlords.
  • The Kols were agitated by the encroachment of dikus (outsiders) on their land and cultural autonomy.
  • Buddha Bhagat mobilized the tribal population to resist British rule and restore their traditional rights.
  • The rebellion turned violent and resulted in attacks on British establishments, but it was eventually suppressed by colonial forces.

Additional Information:

  • The rebellion involved various tribal groups like Ho, Munda, and Oraon under the Kol identity.
  • The British responded by deploying military force and later restructured land administration in the region to avoid future uprisings.

question:
In which region did the Kol rebellion take place in 1831 under the leadership of Budho Bhagat?

66th B.P.S.C (Pre) 2020
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The Kol Rebellion of 1831 led by Budho Bhagat took place in the Singhbhum region, now part of Jharkhand.
  • The rebellion was a reaction to land alienation, economic exploitation, and invasion of outsiders (Dikus) into tribal areas.
  • The Kol tribes, including Ho, Munda, and Oraon, were the main participants.
  • Singhbhum, with its dense forests and hilly terrain, provided a natural base for the tribal uprising.
  • Budho Bhagat emerged as a key leader of resistance during this movement.

Additional Information:

  • The rebellion soon spread to adjoining areas of Ranchi, Hazaribagh, and Palamu.
  • British troops eventually suppressed the rebellion, but it left a lasting mark on tribal resistance movements in India.

question:
Where did the Baghera rebellion occur?

56th to 59th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2015
solution:
• The Baghera Rebellion occurred in the Baroda region, which lies in present-day Gujarat.
  • It was a localised tribal and peasant uprising against the oppressive policies of the princely state of Baroda under British influence.
  • The rebellion was driven by issues such as heavy taxation, land alienation, and exploitation by local rulers.
  • Though not as large-scale as other tribal uprisings, it reflected widespread rural unrest during the 19th century.
  • It was ultimately suppressed by the Baroda administration, with British support.

Additional Information:

  • The rebellion showed early signs of resistance from agrarian communities in western India.
  • It contributed to the broader anti-colonial sentiment that grew over the 19th century.

question:
Arrange the following rebellions that took place in different parts of India before 1857 against the British colonial system in the correct order of events.

(i) Bengal Sepoy Mutiny

(ii) Kutch Rebellion

(iii) Vellore Sepoy Mutiny

(iv) Santhal Rebellion

(v) Kol Rebellion

R.A. S./R.T.S. (Pre) 2013

Code:
solution:
To arrange the rebellions in chronological order (before 1857), we refer to their actual years of occurrence:

  1. Bengal Sepoy Mutiny – 1764
  2. Vellore Sepoy Mutiny – 1806
  3. Kutch Rebellion – 1816
  4. Kol Rebellion – 1831–32
  5. Santhal Rebellion – 1855–56

Now matching this sequence with the given codes:

  • (i) Bengal Sepoy Mutiny – 1764
  • (iii) Vellore Sepoy Mutiny – 1806
  • (ii) Kutch Rebellion – 1816
  • (v) Kol Rebellion – 1831
  • (iv) Santhal Rebellion – 1855

Correct order: (i), (iii), (ii), (v), (iv)

Additional Information:

  • The Bengal Sepoy Mutiny (1764) was an early sign of military discontent under British rule.
  • The Vellore Mutiny was the first large-scale sepoy revolt and a precursor to 1857.
  • The Santhal Rebellion was among the last major tribal uprisings before 1857, with wide tribal mobilization in Jharkhand and Bihar.

question:
Vellore rebellion took place during the tenure of which Governor General?

Chhattisgarh P.C.S. (Pre.) 2016
solution:
• The Vellore Rebellion took place in 1806, making it the first major sepoy uprising against British rule.
  • At that time, Sir George Barlow was serving as the acting Governor-General of India (1805–1807).
  • The rebellion was triggered by religious interference in sepoy dress code and discontent over British policies.
  • It was quickly suppressed but served as a precursor to the 1857 Revolt.
  • Although Lord Wellesley had left office by 1805, some policies from his tenure (like army reforms) contributed indirectly to sepoy resentment.

Additional Information:

  • The revolt occurred in the Vellore Fort (present-day Tamil Nadu) and led to the death of over 100 British soldiers.
  • After this incident, Sir George Barlow withdrew the dress code regulations, trying to avoid further unrest.

question:
When did the Chotanagpur tribal rebellion take place?

39th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1994
solution:
• The Chotanagpur tribal rebellion referred to in this question took place in the year 1820.
  • It was one of the early tribal uprisings in the Chotanagpur plateau region (present-day Jharkhand).
  • This rebellion was a reaction to British land revenue policies, growing control of dikus (outsiders), and encroachment on tribal lands.
  • The movement was led by tribal groups such as the Oraon, Munda, and Ho communities.
  • The rebellion marked the beginning of organized tribal resistance in eastern India.

Additional Information:

  • The Chotanagpur region later witnessed multiple tribal uprisings, such as the Kol Rebellion (1831–32) and Birsa Munda's Ulgulan (1899–1900).
  • These early rebellions laid the groundwork for a sustained anti-colonial struggle among Adivasi communities.

question:
At which place the tribals revolted against the British?

64th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2018
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• Tribal revolts against the British occurred in various parts of India, but Bihar was a major center of several significant tribal uprisings.
  • In Bihar, prominent revolts included:
    • The Santhal Rebellion (1855–56) in present-day Jharkhand (then part of Bihar)
    • The Munda Ulgulan (1899–1900) led by Birsa Munda
    • The Kol Rebellion (1831–32) in the Chotanagpur region
  • These revolts were triggered by land alienation, economic exploitation, and cultural suppression under British rule.
  • The question refers to the general occurrence of tribal revolts, and Bihar fits historically and geographically.

Additional Information:

  • The Santhal Rebellion was one of the largest tribal uprisings in British India.
  • The tribal areas of Bihar played a central role in early resistance movements against British colonialism.

question:
Who led the Santhal rebellion?

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2003
solution:
• The Santhal Rebellion of 1855–56 was a major tribal uprising against the British colonial system.
  • It was jointly led by Sidhu and Kanhu Murmu, along with Bhairav and Chand, who were all Santhal leaders.
  • The rebellion arose due to exploitation by British officials, moneylenders, and zamindars in the Santhal Pargana region (now in Jharkhand).
  • The Santhals declared a form of independent rule and initiated a mass movement against oppressive authorities.
  • Though the British suppressed the rebellion violently, it left a strong mark on tribal resistance history in India.

Additional Information:

  • The British later carved out a separate Santhal Pargana district to better control the region and address tribal issues.
  • The Murmu brothers (Sidhu-Kanhu) are iconic tribal freedom fighters, celebrated annually in Jharkhand and West Bengal.

question:
Who led the Santhal rebellion in 1855?

67th B.P.S.C. (Pre), 2021
option_2: Budhu Bhagat and Teja Bhagat
option_3: Mulu Manek and Jodha Manek
option_4: Madari Pasi and Sahadev
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The Santhal Rebellion of 1855 was led by Sidhu Murmu and Kanhu Murmu, two prominent leaders of the Santhal tribal community.
  • The rebellion took place in the Santhal Pargana region (now in Jharkhand) against the British colonial administration, moneylenders, and zamindars.
  • Sidhu and Kanhu mobilized over 50,000 Santhals in a massive uprising.
  • Their goal was to establish self-rule and resist economic and social exploitation.
  • Despite initial success, the rebellion was eventually crushed by British forces.

Additional Information:

  • The Santhal Rebellion is considered one of the largest tribal uprisings before the 1857 revolt.
  • The Santhal Hul Diwas is celebrated every year in memory of Sidhu and Kanhu's sacrifice.

question:
When among the following did the 'Santhal Rebellion' take place?

B.P.C.S. (Pre) 2016
option_5: None of the above/More than one of the above
solution:
• The Santhal Rebellion, also known as the Santhal Hul, took place during the years 1855–56 A.D.
  • It was led by Sidhu and Kanhu Murmu, and supported by other leaders like Bhairav and Chand.
  • The uprising occurred in the Santhal Pargana region (now in Jharkhand) against British colonial authorities, moneylenders, and zamindars.
  • The rebellion began in June 1855 and was one of the most significant tribal revolts before the 1857 revolt.
  • The British responded with a brutal military crackdown, eventually suppressing the rebellion in early 1856.

Additional Information:

  • The Santhal Rebellion exposed the exploitative structure imposed by the British in tribal regions.
  • In its aftermath, the British created the Santhal Pargana Tenancy Act and formed the Santhal Pargana district to address tribal concerns.

question:

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2011

question:
Who was the leader of 'Santhal Rebellion’?

67th B.P.S.C. (Pre) (Re. Exam), 2021

  • The uprising began in June 1855 in the Santhal Pargana region (now in Jharkhand) to protest against British exploitation, moneylenders, and zamindars.
  • The Murmu brothers declared self-rule and gathered thousands of Santhals in a bold revolt against colonial injustice.

question:
The first tribal leader to be influenced by Mahatma Gandhi and his ideas was-

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2013
solution:
• Alluri Sitarama Raju was the first tribal leader who was notably influenced by Mahatma Gandhi and his ideas of Swaraj (self-rule) and resistance against British rule.
  • He led the Rampa Rebellion (1922–24) in the Eastern Ghats region of Andhra Pradesh, mobilizing tribal peasants against British oppression and forest laws.
  • Though inspired by Gandhi’s ideals, Raju eventually resorted to armed resistance, as peaceful methods failed to protect tribal rights.
  • His movement combined Gandhian inspiration with revolutionary methods, making him a unique figure in India’s freedom struggle.

Additional Information:

  • He was called the “Manyam Veerudu” (Hero of the Forest) by local tribals.
  • He was captured and executed by the British in 1924, becoming a martyr and folk hero in Andhra Pradesh.

question:
Which British commander was defeated by the Santhals in 1855 AD?

47th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 2005
solution:
• In 1855, during the Santhal Rebellion, the Santhal tribals achieved a significant early victory by defeating Major Burrow, a British commander.
  • The battle occurred near Bhognadih (in present-day Jharkhand), where Santhal warriors, under the leadership of Sidhu and Kanhu Murmu, launched a powerful resistance.
  • Major Burrow led a contingent of British troops but was caught in a well-planned ambush by the Santhals and killed in the confrontation.
  • This early success gave the rebellion a strong morale boost and marked a rare tribal military victory over colonial forces.

Additional Information:

  • Despite the early success, the British soon responded with heavy reinforcements and brutally suppressed the rebellion by 1856.
  • The event proved that tribal uprisings had the potential to challenge colonial military might under effective leadership.

question:
With reference to the 'Santhal Hul' of 1855, which of the following statements is/are correct?

Choose the correct answer from the code given below-

Major Baro lost the battle to the Santhals near Bhagalpur.

2. Gokko was an important leader of Godda.

U.P. P.C.S. (Mains) 2017

Codes:
solution:
Let’s examine each statement in relation to the Santhal Hul (1855–56):

  1. Major Barrow lost the battle to the Santhals near Bhagalpur – ✅ Correct
    • Major Burrow (often spelled Baro) was defeated and killed by the Santhals in an early battle near Bhognadih, which is close to Bhagalpur (now in Jharkhand).
  2. Gokko was an important leader of Godda – ✅ Correct
    • Gokko was indeed a prominent Santhal leader from the Godda district who played an important role in mobilizing tribal forces during the rebellion.
  3. Mahajan Deen Dayal Rai is also an important name in this context – ✅ Correct
    • Deen Dayal Rai, a moneylender (mahajan), was a key local figure often mentioned in the context of Santhal oppression and the rebellion’s targets.

    • The Santhal Hul was primarily centered in Santhal Pargana, Bhagalpur, Dumka, and adjoining areas. Muzaffarpur is located in north Bihar, far from the Santhal stronghold, and Santhals never dominated the Ganga valley near Muzaffarpur.

question:

solution:

  1. State territories called 'Santhal Parganas' were created – ✅ Correct

question:
What was the Santhal Pargana region called in ancient times?

Jharkhand P.C.S. (Pre) 2016
solution:
• In ancient times, the region now known as Santhal Pargana was called Narikhand.
  • This name appears in historical and geographical references related to early eastern Indian territories.
  • The area was densely forested and inhabited by tribal communities even before colonial classification.
  • The term “Santhal Pargana” was officially introduced by the British after the Santhal Rebellion (1855–56) to designate a special administrative zone.

Additional Information:

  • Santhal Pargana today includes districts like Dumka, Godda, Sahibganj, Deoghar, Pakur, and parts of Jamtara.
  • It became a focal point of tribal resistance movements and still holds cultural and political significance in Jharkhand.

question:
Which of the following events occurred in Maharashtra?

U.P. P.C.S. (Pre) 1998
solution:
• The Bhil Rebellion occurred in the Maharashtra region, making it the correct answer.
  • The Bhil tribe primarily resides in Khandesh, Satpura ranges, and parts of western Maharashtra.
  • After the Third Anglo-Maratha War (1818), the Bhils rebelled against the British due to land dispossession, harsh revenue demands, and loss of traditional autonomy.
  • These rebellions occurred intermittently between 1818 and 1831 and were met with severe British military responses.

Additional Information:

  • To control the Bhils, the British later formed the Bhil Corps, recruiting Bhils into local military units.
  • The rebellion was part of a larger pattern of tribal unrest following British annexation of Maratha territories.

question:
Who initiated the 'Lasodia Movement' for social reform among the Bhils of Mewar, Bangar and nearby areas?

R.A.S./R.T.S. (Pre) 2008
solution:
• The Lasodia Movement was initiated by Govind Giri (also known as Govind Guru) among the Bhil tribes of Mewar, Bangar, and surrounding regions.
  • The movement aimed at social and moral reform, promoting abstinence from alcohol, vegetarianism, and rejection of exploitative customs.
  • Govind Giri sought to awaken the Bhils to self-respect, discipline, and unity, inspired by Bhagat religious traditions.
  • Over time, this reform movement took on a political tone, culminating in the Mangadh Hill resistance in 1913 against British and princely forces.

Additional Information:

  • Govind Giri’s followers were known as Bhagats, and he is still venerated among tribal communities in Rajasthan and Gujarat.
  • The Mangadh massacre (1913), where British troops opened fire on tribal protestors, is seen as a tragic turning point in this movement.

question:
With whom was the Ulgulan rebellion associated?

39th B.P.S.C. (Pre) 1994
solution:
• The Ulgulan Rebellion is associated with Birsa Munda, a legendary tribal freedom fighter.
  • "Ulgulan" means "Great Tumult" or Rebellion in the local Munda language.
  • This movement took place in the Chotanagpur region (present-day Jharkhand) during 1899–1900.
  • It was aimed against British colonial rule, exploitative landlords, and the missionary interference in tribal culture.
  • Birsa Munda mobilized the Munda tribal community to restore traditional rights over forest and land.

Additional Information:

  • Though Birsa Munda was captured and died in 1900, he is the only tribal leader whose portrait is displayed in the Indian Parliament.
  • The Ulgulan played a major role in the formation of the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act, 1908, which provided land rights to tribals.

question:
In the context of the history of India, 'Ulgulan' or the Great Trouble was a description of which of the following events?

I.A.S. (Pre) 2020
option_2: The Moplah revolt of 1921
option_3: The Indigo revolt of 1859-60
option_4: The Birsa Munda revolt of 1899-1900
solution:
• The term 'Ulgulan', meaning "Great Tumult" or "Great Revolt", refers to the Birsa Munda-led tribal uprising in the Chotanagpur region during 1899–1900.
  • It was a revolt against British colonial rule, feudal landlords (dikus), and missionary activities interfering with tribal customs and land rights.
  • Led by Birsa Munda, the movement aimed to restore tribal autonomy, establish Munda Raj, and resist land alienation.
  • Though the rebellion was suppressed and Birsa died in 1900, the movement led to landmark reforms in tribal land rights.

Additional Information:

  • The rebellion resulted in the Chotanagpur Tenancy Act of 1908, securing land rights for tribal communities.
  • Birsa Munda is celebrated as a folk hero and tribal icon, and his legacy is central to Jharkhand’s identity today.
